result.execSummary:
The defendant Coleton P Schry was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Possession of Narcotic Drugs [Modifiers: Possession of a Controlled Substance on or near Certain Places], a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(3g)(am).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

superMiscConds.notes: Court orders the fines, costs, and restitution in this file shall be paid from all funds received into the defendant's prison accounts in accordance with prison policy, not to exceed 25% of gross during the term of initial confinement. If any fines, costs, and/or restitution remain outstanding at the end of the initial confinement portion of this sentence, then the remaining shall be paid as a condition of extended supervision.  If probation/supervision is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.

Defendant is to submit a DNA Sample.

records.descr: Notice of court ordered financial obligations

records.addlTxt: Order / Judgment Extending Probation for Unpaid Court Obligations (1 year-11/30/2021; jail time if not paid)
Order / Judgment Extending Probation for Unpaid Court Obligations (1 year-11/30/2021; jail time if not paid)
Defendant and Agent Helmuth appeared via zoom conferencing.
Spoke with Danielle at GLSO.

9:48 a.m. Defendant appears in custody, by video, and without counsel. Agent Ryan Helmuth appears by phone. Court quashes warrant issued on Monday. Defendant says he will pay all obligations by October 30, 2020. Court notes nothing has been paid on this case at all. Defendant states he was paying on other cases. Defendant states he believes he can pay by probation expiration date, which is November 30, 2020. Court finds defendant has not made a good faith effort, after having previous extentions and extends probation for an addtional year. However, if paid by 11/30/20, probation can expire. If not, defendant to spend 30 days in jail. Court does not grant huber, out of county service or out of county travel. Defendant to report to jail on or before 11/30/20 if obligations not paid. If not paid by the end of January, Court orders an additional 60 days in jail, no huber, out of county service or out of county travel. Agent Helmuth to submit order. Court adjourned at 9:52 a.m.

Warrant sent down to GLSo on 10/12/2020.

Probation review hearing on October 12, 2020 at 09:00 am.

records.addlTxt: of hearing held on May 31, 2016, before Hon Mark T. Slate - Circuit Court Judge, by Karen Blair - Court Reporter
No Victims in the case - per VWC.

2:02 p.m.  Defendant present in court with Atty John Selsing.  Andrew Christenson for the State of Wisconsin.  Court recites agreement - defendant will plea to the Burglary and Possession charges and the balance of the counts will be dismissed and read-in.  State concurs.  Defendant concurs.

Court goes over plea questionnaire with the defendant.  Court goes over constitutional rights with the defendant - defendant waives these rights.  Court goes over the elements of each offense.  Court instructs defendant of the maximum penalty.  Court instructs defendant regarding deportation.  (If felony) Court instructs regarding felony prohibitions.

Defendant enters a plea of NO CONTEST.  Court finds the plea is made freely, voluntarily, intelligently and understandingly.  Court finds there is a factual basis to support the plea.  Court finds the defendant guilty on count 1 as charged in 2015CF64 and orders the balance of the counts be dismissed and read-in.  Court finds the defendant guilty on count 1 as charged in 2015CF12 and orders the balance of the counts be dismissed and read-in.  Court orders the judgment of conviction be entered here today.  DA confirms compliance with victim witness rights.  Sentencing statement by DA.  Statement by Atty Selsing.  Statement by the defendant.

Court sentences the defendant to:

2015CF12 (Burglary)

15 months of Initial Confinement and 4 years of Extended Supervision.

CONDITIONS:

-Court costs.  Court orders the fines, costs, and restitution in this file shall be paid from all funds received into the defendant's prison accounts in accordance with prison policy, not to exceed 25% of gross during the term of initial confinement. If any fines, costs, and/or restitution remain outstanding at the end of the initial confinement portion of this sentence, then the remaining shall be paid as a condition of extended supervision.  If probation/supervision is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.
-Restitution - $370.45.  Court orders the fines, costs, and restitution in this file shall be paid from all funds received into the defendant's prison accounts in accordance with prison policy, not to exceed 25% of gross during the term of initial confinement. If any fines, costs, and/or restitution remain outstanding at the end of the initial confinement portion of this sentence, then the remaining shall be paid as a condition of extended supervision.  If probation/supervision is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.
-letter of Apology
-No Contact with the victim or victims residence.  Forms of no contact include: in person, in writing, by telephone, by e-mail, or by any other forms of electronic communication, or through a third party intending to circumvent the no contact provision, without the permission of the agent.
-Defendant is to abide by all rules and recommendations of the supervising agent.
-DNA sample

2015CF64(Poss)

1 1/2 years of Initial Confinement, consecutive to any other sentence and 2 years of Extended Supervision, stayed and places the defendant on probation for 3 years, consecutive to any other sentence. 

CONDITIONS:

-Court costs.Court orders the fines, costs, and restitution in this file shall be paid from all funds received into the defendant's prison accounts in accordance with prison policy, not to exceed 25% of gross during the term of initial confinement. If any fines, costs, and/or restitution remain outstanding at the end of the initial confinement portion of this sentence, then the remaining shall be paid as a condition of extended supervision.  If probation/supervision is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.
-DNA sample

Court orders the cash bonds on file be applied to the restitution first, then the court costs.

Court remands the defendant to the custody of the Sheriff's Dept.

Court adjourned at 2:22 p.m.


Note:  After court I questioned Judge about the Challenge Incarceration Program and the Substance Abuse Program as it was not mentioned in court.  Per Judge - yes to both.
